11:14 am
PM

Seen this Merrill note this morning?

PM

Benchmarking the bear: more 1998 than
2008

PM

Key takeaways
• EU equities oversold (high cash levels and AAII net bulls at 3rd %ile).
• Market shock (1998) not crisis (2008). Large EPS recession less likely than prior bear
markets and systemic risks lower.
• Triggers? Stabilizing growth data, easier CB policy, stable oil. O/W yield, DM greater tahn EM,
select cyclicality and Health above Staples.

11:16 am
PM

Heres the rest of the front page

PM

EU equities in bear market territory & heavily oversold The 21% sell-off in European equities has taken us into bear market territory. Technical
and sentiment metrics have moved decisively to oversold levels. 6-month returns are 5th
percentile and AAII sentiment survey is 3rd percentile since 1987. Cash levels are high.
Market shock not recession, more 1998 than 2008 Despite a large market decline in 1998 recession in DM economies and earnings was
avoided and they grew strongly again in 1999. Although EM is larger today our
economists argue the EM/commodity downturn is manageable for DM and do not expect
a broader recession. Recent data is encouraging, with strong European PMIS but also
signs of stabilisation in US manufacturing (Philly Fed, ISM new orders) and China
(BofAML ACT growth tracker). Corporate and bank leverage is lower now than in 2008.
Benchmarking vs previous bear markets Bigger bear markets than this one usually preceded large EPS recessions or started from
more expensive valuations. Current multiples are above many prior troughs but we see
lower EPS risk this time (strong EU data & ROE/EPS not stretched). In addition, with
very low bond yields equity valuations look much more attractive on a relative basis. The
DY to bund yield spread is 3.0% - above all prior market troughs bar March 2009.

PM

Equities in buy territory – watch oil, US data & CB policy We have stressed the need to be tactical as regulation and trading patterns drive less
liquid markets that are more prone to large swings. With a constructive view on
fundamentals we would add risk into current weakness. Stabilizing growth indicators,
easier less tight CB policy and beaten up technicals sentiment are encouraging signs
already, but equity and credit markets may need stability in oil markets to rally. The ECB
today indicated more and expanded easing is likely in March, while the PBoC has
achieved some stability in CNY. Stability in oil is key from here.
O/W yield, DM-EM, select cyclicality and Health -Staples We advocate sustainable DY in Europe and a preference for DM over EM. That leads to
OW in Tech, Media, Industrials and Banks and UW in Basic Resources, Autos & Staples.
The escalation of NPL / capital concerns in Italy may represent a downside risk to our
Banks OW, but we don’t expect liquidity or sovereign strains. Both Health and Staples
have performed defensively in the sell-off but we prefer the former on fundamentals.

BE

(@Boncoeur: you're correct, that is pedantic.)

BE

BE

Well, that's not the reason it's up. But it's a convenient peg on which to hang today's move.

11:21 am
BE

Time to Buy
We resume coverage on Antofagasta, following a restriction period, and upgrade from Sell to Buy with a £4.40/share price target (having been sellers since 2012). The stock has lost ~75% of its value over the past three years and has relative scarcity within the mining sector given its strong balance sheet, ability to self-fund at spot prices, and pure exposure to a structurally deficit commodity. We see ANTO as a "trough cycle survivor" which should appeal to investors despite the risk of a further copper price decline. Spot 2017F attributable EV/EBITDA at 7.2x, while not cheap, is still significantly below the likes of SCCO and BHP.

BE

Trough Cycle Survivor
We calculate 1.3x 2017F Net Debt/EBITDA at spot copper. The company is FCF neutral at current copper prices in 2017+ (negative 2016 due to Encuentro capex). Volume growth is limited until Los Pelambres expansion or second Centinela concentrator; but we see value at current levels, even ex-growth.

BE

Copper Structurally Good, Technically Challenged
Citi’s global commodity team maintains a positive outlook for copper, viewing 2Q16 as the trough in the price (averaging $4,300/t). Structural deficits are expected to emerge in 2020+, exacerbated by the current downturn and lack of investment. Yet, short-term we do acknowledge the downside price risks.

11:21 am
BE

Zaldivar Incorporated and Other Key Changes in Our Model
Earnings uplift from Zaldivar is more than offset by a significantly lower copper price forecast, resulting in greater than 50% EPS downgrades for 2015-17F. NPV has dropped to £5.0/sh from £6.8/sh. Price target based on NPV and multiples based valuation methods is cut to £4.40/sh from £6.0/sh due to lower NPV and earnings.

BE

4Q 2015 Production Report on 27th January and 2016 Roadmap
We expect 731kt copper guidance @$1.48/lb C1 for 2016. Key 2016 events include ramp-up of Antucoya, Encuentro oxides first production, integration and potential revised mine plan at Zaldivar, EIA submission for Los Pelambres (LP) expansion, Centinela Moly plant construction, and progress/resolution of LP lawsuit.

PM

PM

Slashing capital expenditure and even cutting its dividend to zero are not sufficient for BHP to realistically retain a 'solid A' credit rating, if spot commodity prices and currencies persist. Given the company continues to be married to the idea of a ‘solid A’ rating throughout the cycle, a rights issue looks likely. The threat of a capital call will weigh on the shares, but its resolution, in conjunction with self-help measures of tighter capital spend and a reduced dividend, would close the value gap to Rio.

BE

This is Richard Knights, who's generally accepted to be good.

BE

Here are the bullet points.

11:31 am
BE

To maintain a ‘solid A’ rating, BHP should be able to demonstrate a path to FFO/Net Debt greater than 40%. At spot prices, our costs, currently guided capex and divi, it is greater than $20bn short.

PM

Welcome

BE

Cutting $2bn from capex in FY’17 goes a long way to narrowing the FCF yield gap vs. Rio. In conjunction with a rights issue, BHP’s val’n and B/S would look favourable to Rio.

11:32 am
BE

Our new TP of £5.50 is set at a 30% discount to our base case NPV, reflecting downside risk to our current medium-term copper and oil assumptions.

PM

Here's Neil Collins on the matter:

PM

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3xyJ4dml2

11:32 am
PM

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz3xyKJ7GTI

CS add that even a halved dividend would be uncovered by free cash flow at today’s prices for iron ore, copper and oil. The brokers suggest replacing part of the cash dividend with new shares. This would preserve the delusion that the payout was somehow being maintained, but in today’s panicking markets, few investors would be fooled by what is, in effect, a mini rights issue. BHP, which once considered itself the top dog miner, should suspend dividend payments until it is clear how much it can afford to pay. If that means Mr Mackenzie has to go too, it would be a just reward for failing to take the chance when it presented itself.

BE

Yeah, stealth rights issue. Up to 12% of equity if they go scrip.

BE

I think it's an interesting solution. But then, I'm not a shareholder.

11:44 am
BE

I do. Shore.

BE

Close Brothers has issued a scheduled trading update covering five months of performance from 1st August 2015 to 31st December 2015, which includes an additional two months of data for November and December on which the company had previously not reported. While performance of the Banking division is broadly as we had anticipated and is consistent with Q1 trends, both Winterflood and Asset Management have continued to be negatively impacted by weak market conditions, both during the period under reference and since the start of the new calendar year.

BE

Fair value estimate reduced to 1,425p (from 1,455p); Hold stance re-iterated
At a share price of 1,275p and based on our revised estimates, Close Brothers is trading on y/e July 2016F PER of 10.6x, dividend yield of 4.5% and a P/TNAV of 2.0x for an ROTE of 19.9%. The shares have fallen by 23% since reaching a peak of 1,654p in March 2015 and are now trading at a 10% discount to our revised fair value estimate of 1,425p (previously: 1,455p).

Although our formal recommendation remains HOLD, we would not be averse to investors picking up stock at current levels in what we view to be a high quality company, noting that the Banking division remains the key value driver for the group, where our full year forecasts appear to be well underpinned.

11:45 am
BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

Compared to the commentary in November, today’s update from
Close is slightly more cautious given the headwinds for the
market sensitive divisions. By contrast, the Bank remains a
beacon of solidity. We see upside in the shares, given the
valuation, but reduce our target price given difficult conditions.

BE

 Overall. Close Bros IMS this morning covers the five-month period to 31
December, ahead of interim results (on 10 March). Overall, the message is
slightly more cautious than the commentary in November, although the overall
message remains confidence in delivering a satisfactory outcome for the full
year. In our view, this highlights the benefits of the group’s diversity, with a
stronger performance from Banking offsetting a weaker performance from
Securities and Asset Management.
 Banking. Continuing the trend of the past few years, the Bank has delivered
another period of solid growth. The loan book has grown by 5% over the
period to £6.0bn, with the trends similar to those reported previously in that
the net interest margin has reduced but this has been offset by a slight
improvement in the bad-debt ratio. We are expecting loan book growth of just
over 8% for the full year, which looks conservative given the growth to date.
The impairment charge was already running at historically low levels and a
further improvement highlights the controlled growth Close is delivering, but
also the benefit from the continuing benign conditions.
 Securities. As noted in November, the more challenging market conditions
continue to impact Winterflood’s performance. Profits are lower than in the
prior year, given lower equity markets and levels of activity. As has typically
been the case, increased risk aversion means the impact of lower trading
activity is more pronounced in higher margin AIM stocks. Our forecasts had
already assumed a decline in Winterflood’s profitability, although conditions
have deterioarated further since we reviewed expectations.
 Asset Management. The Asset Management business continues to make
progress, although lower equity markets and the disposal of the group’s
corporate activities has reduced the level of AuM to £9.4bn (from £10.8bn at
the start of the year). Net inflows are reported as solid, although there is no
commentary on the quantum.
 Impact on forecasts. Our forecasts are for PBT/EPS of £237.5m/126.4p,
slightly ahead of consensus, which presently stands at £232m/124p. Given the
general tone of this morning’s statement, we would expect to (modestly)
reduce our estimates. The impact on the overall group from reducing forecasts
for WINS and Asset management will be relatively modest, given the
proportion of the group’s earnings that come from the Banking division.
 Valuation and recommendation. On our estimates, Close trades on a July
2016 PER of 10.0x, whilst yielding 4.6%. which does not look overly
demanding. We maintain our Buy recommendation, although to take account
of the more difficult environment, and sentiment towards market sensitive
earnings streams, we reduce our target price to 1,600p (from 1,800p)
previously.

XenoPort, a US small-cap drug maker and former GlaxoSmithKline partner, is a rumoured takeover target for sector peer Supernus Pharmaceuticals.

According to usually reliable people, Supernus has put an offer on the table of around $7.40 per share for XenoPort, which would value the latter at $470m. Takeover speculation has already lifted XenoPort by 18 per cent in the past week, taking its gain over the past month to 40 per cent after the company effectively put itself up for sale.

undefined
PM

We don't often look at Sterling

11:48 am
PM

But wow, it's had a tough time

PM

Actualy, UBS saying its pretty unprecedented in 20 years

PM

Of the many violent recent moves in global markets, the collapse of sterling is one of
the most remarkable. In trade weighted terms, the currency has dropped more than
7% in just two months, a fall of a magnitude only surpassed once since the MPC
assumed responsibility for setting UK monetary policy in 1997.

11:49 am
PM

This is John Wraith at UBS

PM

No obvious fundamental justification for the scale of this fall
The only time sterling dropped more sharply than in the current episode was during the
Global Financial Crisis, when the UK's particularly acute exposure to the financial sector
caused the economy to crash more emphatically than any other major country. A trade
weighted currency adjustment of such magnitude is typically triggered by just such a
relative shift in a particular country's economic fortunes. During the latest currency
capitulation, no such trigger is immediately identifiable.

PM

He's stumped

11:50 am
PM

Recent activity trends provide no explanation
The suddenness of recent market volatility means there is a lack of comprehensive
empirical evidence to assess, but one useful gauge is the composite PMI series, a long
established and comparable barometer of sentiment across a range of countries and
areas. If anything, this analysis paints the UK in a relatively favourable light, as the
major economy which saw the largest rise in the index in the fourth quarter of 2008,
taking it to a level only surpassed by Germany.

PM

Just stumped

PM

Interest rate differentials don't provide a causal link
Evolving relative changes in front end interest rates between countries can be a key
driver of exchange rates. This was certainly the case between sterling and the US dollar
until late last year (and to a lesser extent between sterling and the euro). However,
cable has tumbled by more than 8% since the start of November despite almost no
change in the spread between 1y swap rates, 1y forward, in the UK and the US.

11:50 am
PM

No clue whatsoever

PM

Correlation between FX and commodity exposure holds no key
The huge fall in global commodity prices has been a clear influence on many currencies
of late, with those of net exporters such as Russia, Australia, Canada and Brazil falling
sharply in trade weighted terms. Most importers, on the other hand, have seen a clear
appreciation. The performance of sterling is one glaring exception to the latter group.

PM

So...blame Brexit threat

11:51 am
PM

Which seems a fair thing to do

PM

Pointing the finger of blame at Brexit…
We believe the explanation for the move lies in the future, not the past. A big increase
in the focus on the UK's EU referendum – which may well be held by the middle of the
year – and a concomitant shift in opinion polls that points to an ever closer outcome
provide a compelling argument to explain the pound's demise.
…while the UK's current account deficit compounds the problem
Recent years of strong UK demand relative to that in other European countries have
seen the persistent trade deficit of the UK grow rapidly, driving the current account
deficit to ever higher levels. Dependence on external financing and the risk of capital
outflows this generates make potential downside risks to the currency even more
acute.

PM

Sterling has fallen more than recent events justify, but drivers could intensify
Concerns around the risk of Brexit are likely to get more serious as the referendum
approaches. This could exacerbate the downside pressure on sterling, as could worries
over the current account deficit. We do not therefore advocate positioning for a
reversal of the recent spiral lower.

11:52 am
PM

So sterling "oversold" but could become more so

undefined

Blinkx PLC (BLNX:LSE): Last: 20.06, down 1.19 (-5.59%), High: 21.25, Low: 19.75, Volume: 672.10k
PM

(Penny -- see yesterday's caht)

11:55 am
PM

Poor Blinkx. We really beat that one up

BE

Singlehurst at Citi has downgraded.

BE

It's part of a gigantic media note. As in, gigantic.

11:56 am
BE

You have to cut to page 62 (of 136) to find the explanation.

BE

The explanation being it's a not very good business that torches cash.

BE

What's Changing? — Despite the encouraging 3Q trading performance, we
substantially pull back our forecasts of EBITDA (-60% in 2017E) to reflect the
challenges of the desktop to mobile migration outlined at the 1H results in
November. We see Blinkx as a survivor and see decent support from the net
cash balance, but it is difficult to see what would drive a further rerating while the
group generates limited cash flow. Reflecting this we move our rating to Neutral
and our PT on the group to 24p.
 Our View — Blinkx has had a torrid few years and continues to grapple with
some of the big megatrends buffeting the online advertising ecosystem, namely
concerns over viewability/verification, the migration from desktop to mobile from
display to video and from direct sales to programmatic and the increased
dominance of the larger internet groups. In this context, Blinkx’s performance has
actually been quite strong: although revenue has disappointed, the group has
continually taken out costs and limited (although not avoided) cash burn. We do
see the group eventually returning to growth and we think valuation is
underpinned at current levels but the investment is sufficiently long duration that
it is difficult to make the case that it is must own near-term. Reflecting this we
rate the group as a Neutral.

11:57 am
BE

Where Do We Stand vs. Consensus? — There is not a well-established
consensus on Blinkx, at least in terms of forecasts. It is fair to say, however, that
we are probably more optimistic than most investors on the LT prospects of the
group.
 Forecast Changes — We have substantially reduced our revenue and EBITDA
forecasts not necessarily to reflect the most recent commentary – the 3Q trading,
as reported by the company, was relatively robust – but rather to reflect the
broader structural issues outlined at the 1H. Because the group is loss making at
the EPS level, the percentage changes are not meaningful. At the EBITDA level,
however, the downgrades are material – we reduce 2017E revenue by c. 21%
and on the back of this reduce 2017E EBITDA by c. 60%.
 Changes to Valuation — There are various difficulties in valuing Blinkx given the
fledgling nature of its business and the lack of obvious comparable companies.
The recent move into cash burn further complicates issues. With this in mind,
DCF is the most appropriate valuation analysis, in our view. Based on a discount
rate of 10% and LT growth of 2% (reduced from 5% given challenging
fundamentals), we derive a FV of 24p and use this as the basis of our PT.

BE

2015 turned out to be a very ‘thematic’ year.
Through the year the media sector was buffeted by concerns about changing media
consumption habits, rising concerns about disintermediation and print/digital
migration. The net result was a surprisingly wide divergence in sub-sector multiple
performance (outdoor rerated 24% while FTA TV derated by -3%). We expect more
of the same in 2016 and identify seven key themes: (1) rising non-linear viewing; (2)
the spectre of structural pressure on agencies; (3) growth in music streaming; (4)
trends in educational publishing; (5) pressure on academic publishing; (6) the
implications of online ad fraud/ad blocking; (7) growing focus on data privacy.

BE

Cutting a bit of the prognostication ..... In terms of recommendations:

12:00 pm
BE

The utopian ideal would be a company
with low systemic risk, great company fundamentals, EPS upgrade potential and
attractive cash-based valuation. Sky, in our view, comes closest, although we also
highlight TF1 and WPP as companies that screen well. TF1 for its low systemic risk,
potential EPS upside and strong balance sheet; WPP for its strong near-term EPS
momentum and structural positioning. Both also have attractive cash based
valuation. On the negative side we focus on companies with high systemic risk,
earnings risk and stretched valuation. Our key Sells are INF, WKL, SBTA and VIV.
